citation.article-title: Herminiimonas glaciei sp. nov., a novel ultramicrobacterium from 3042 m deep Greenland glacial ice.
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Herminiimonas glaciei sp. nov.
Herminiimonas glaciei (gla.ci.e′i. L. gen. n. glaciei of ice, in reference to the Greenland glacier).
Cells are small, thin rods, 0.5–0.9×0.3–0.4 μm with a mean volume of 0.043 μm3.
Cells stain Gram-negative and have 1 or 2 polar and/or 1–3 lateral very long flagella.
Original colony pigmentation is brown-purple.
After recultivation on TSA without glucose, colonies are circular with an entire edge, convex, smooth, and translucent white to tan coloured.
Temperature range for growth is 1–35 °C; optimum growth occurs at 30 °C with a doubling time of 4 h in TSB without glucose.
Grows in mineral salts medium with ammonium chloride as the sole source of nitrogen.
No vitamins are required for growth.
Sole carbon sources include citrate, lactate, malate, succinate and alanine.
Does not use formate, capric acid, adipic acid, phenylacetic acid, potassium gluconate, d-glucose, l-arabinose, d-mannose, d-mannitol, N-acetylglucosamine or maltose as sole carbon sources.
Cells are oxidase- and catalase-positive.
Produces acid from l-arabinose, d-arabinose, l-xylose, d-xylose and d-ribose and weakly from d-galactose, d-lyxose, d-fucose and l-fucose.
Does not reduce nitrate or produce indole, urease or arginine dihydrolyase.
Does not hydrolyse gelatin, aesculin or p-nitrophenyl β-d-galactopyranoside (PNPG).
Does not hydrolyse skimmed milk (casein), starch, DNA, X-Gal, Tween 80 or lecithin.
Major fatty acids are C16 : 0, C17 : 0 cyclo and C16 : 1ω7c.
Resistant to ampicillin, bacitracin, chloramphenicol, ciprofloxacin, penicillin, nalidixic acid, rifampicin, streptomycin and vancomycin.
Sensitive to gentamicin, neomycin and tetracycline.
The DNA G+C content of the type strain is 59.0 mol%.

The type strain, UMB49T (=ATCC BAA-1623T=DSM 21140T), was isolated from a 3042 m deep, 120 000-year-old Greenland glacier ice core sample, after 0.2 μm filtration and low-temperature (2 °C) enrichment procedure.
